transcription.text:
Japanese Shadow Cards (French made) circa 1880

Cardboard box containing 9 x 'Shadow Puppet', game cards. Cards are mono coloured printed onto individual pieces of cardboard; each card depicts a different illustration of a hand gesture to produced a shadow puppet effect. Box is red with a printed label on front with coloured type 'L.E.S OMBRES JAPONAISES W.X.Paris.'.

Laura Poitras blurs the line between documentary and investigative journalism. Poitras was one of three journalists confided in by whistleblower Edward Snowden when he shared classified documents that detailed global government surveillance. Telling his story earned Poitras a Pulitzer, while Citizenfour won an Oscar.

work.title: Laura Poitras in New York City

transcription.text: Las Patronas, Mexican women's group giving food aid to migrants crossing the border

work.title: Las Patronas, Mexican women's group giving food aid to migrants crossing the border

transcription.text: Las Patronas (The Bosses), a group of Mexican volunteers, have been passing food and water to South and Central American migrants heading to the US border on top of freight trains. This video has been widely shared and celebrated on social media, highlighting the compassion being shown to migrants on the US/Mexico border. Some viewers have questioned if its virality puts the work in danger, but  Las Patronas shared the original video to raise awareness and fund their work. According to a 2014 article, the group was formed 19 years earlier, so they've been helping people for almost 30 years – far longer than social media has been around.

Animation device called Zoetrope and assorted animation strips. Body of Zoetrope is a cylinder formation closed on bottom and open at top with a series of slits around top rim and painted green. Wood spindle joins cylinder to metal tiered stand. Zoetrope has five various themed printed paper animation strips depicting illustrations of a sequence of drawings showing motion. Animation strips are either black and white or mono coloured with an animation on both sides.

work.title: Large green zoetrope with metal base

transcription.text: Australia's First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today. The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
A compliation of moments from various 'home movies' in the ACMI Collection.

work.title: La lanterne magique (The Magic Lantern) Thaumatrope verso

transcription.text: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.

work.title: La lanterne magique (The Magic Lantern) thaumatrope

transcription.text: This newsreel gave Australians the first glimpse of fighting on the Kokoda Trail and was used as propaganda. Photographer Damien Parer and director Ken G Hall restaged several combat scenes and asked viewers to join the war effort. In 1943, it won Australia’s first Oscar.
